topics.title: Radical accountability and early growth mindset
topics.summary: Chris describes HubSpot’s tiny early growth team taking ownership of neglected self-serve revenue, “blowing it up,” and using radical accountability to find and solve problems the business wasn’t explicitly asking for.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces the show and Chris Miller, outlining Chris’s path from early growth work at HubSpot to leading Growth and AI, plus what the conversation will cover.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Vanta (security compliance automation) and Sidebar (peer groups/personal board of directors).

topics.title: VP of Product for Growth and AI
topics.summary: Chris explains his role spanning PLG and AI: building foundational AI tech and turning it into AI-powered experiences that help SMBs succeed on HubSpot.

topics.title: How Chris earned broader leadership scope
topics.summary: Chris attributes his trajectory to timing (post-free CRM launch), a growth-PM lens, pushing into strategic conversations, and building context through cross-functional curiosity and in-person serendipity.

topics.title: Taking risks: the Guinness pricing pitch
topics.summary: Chris shares a story of crashing a Guinness event, pitching a contrarian pricing/packaging idea to the COO, and earning an invite to present to executives—opening doors for future influence.

topics.title: Traits of great growth PMs
topics.summary: Chris lists what he hires for: relentless curiosity, resilience (given high experiment failure rates), coachability, and creativity/comfort with simple solutions over complex ones.

topics.title: Breaking into product management
topics.summary: Chris recounts Googling “product management” and asking to do it, then advises aspiring PMs to choose environments with strong structure, seek hands-on exposure, and volunteer to help PMs to earn sponsorship.

topics.title: Learning PM craft: customers, data, and rigor
topics.summary: Chris contrasts a B2B2C role with limited end-user access versus a freemium B2C app where direct user research and large-scale data enabled hypothesis-driven decisions and accelerated his PM growth.

topics.title: Mentors vs sponsors and seeking hard feedback
topics.summary: Chris distinguishes mentors from sponsors/advocates who spend political capital, and shares how coachability, ego-free learning, and embracing tough feedback help attract people willing to invest in you.

topics.title: What makes HubSpot special: customers and market focus
topics.summary: Chris highlights true customer obsession, long-term decision-making, and HubSpot’s choice to stay focused on SMB/mid-market—avoiding enterprise hostage dynamics and prioritizing broad customer benefit.

topics.title: Culture code and evolving rituals
topics.summary: Chris explains HubSpot’s public culture code, the need to re-evaluate legacy in-jokes for inclusivity, and describes PEER Week as a key ritual for connection and in-person collaboration.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Merge (Unified API for integrations across HR, accounting, ATS, ticketing, CRM, etc.).

topics.title: Transition to HubSpot growth history and PLG roots
topics.summary: Lenny pivots to how HubSpot grew; Chris begins by pointing to early freemium years and credits Brian Balfour for injecting early PLG DNA into HubSpot.
